citation.article-title: Taxonomic studies of deep-sea barophilic Shewanella strains and description of Shewanella violacea sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Shewanella violacea sp. nov.
Shewanella violacea (vi.o.lace.a. L.gen.n. violacea, of violet.)
Cells are rod-shaped; cell width ranges from 0.8 to 1.0 μm, and cell length ranges from 2 to 4 μm.
Cells are gram-negative and motile by means of a single, unsheathed polar flagellum.
Colonies on Marine Agar 2216 are entire, smooth, semitranslucent, and nonpigmented, 2–4 mm in diameter following 2–3 days of incubation at 8°C at atmospheric pressure.
After 7 days of incubation at 8°C at atmospheric pressure, the colonies display a violet pigment.
This bacterium is halophilic, psychrophilic, and moderately barophilic.
Optimal growth occurs at an NaCl concentration of ca. 3%.
No growth occurs in the absence of NaCl.
The optimal temperature and pressure for growth are 8°C and 30 MPa, respectively.
No growth occurs at over 20°C.
It is a facultatively anaerobic chemoorganotroph having both respiratory and fermentative types of metabolism.
Catalase and cytochrome oxidase tests are positive.
Acids are produced from D-glucose with gas.
The organism does not produce H2 S.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite.
Arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, and ornithine decarboxylase tests are negative.
Acid is formed oxidatively from cellobiose, D-galactose, and D-glucose.
No acid is produced from arabinose, D-fructose, glycerol, inositol, D-lactose, maltose, D-mannitol, D-mannose, D-raffinose, L-rhamnose, D-sorbitol, sucrose, D-trehalose, or xylose.
The G+C content of the DNA is approximately 47 mol%.
The major isoprenoid quinone is Q-8.
The dominant cellular fatty acids are iso-15:0, 16:0, 16:1, and 20:5(ω3).
The type strain is S. violacea strain DSS12, which has been deposited in the Japan Collection of Microorganisms (Wako-shi, Saitama, Japan) as strain JCM 10179.
